abreast: alongside each other, facing in the same direction
abscission: the act of cutting something off
abscond: run away, often taking something or somebody along
accede: yield to another's wish or opinion
accretion: an increase by natural growth or addition
adulterate: make impure by adding a foreign or inferior substance
adumbrate: describe roughly or give the main points or summary of
aerie: the lofty nest of a bird of prey, such as a hawk or eagle

amortization: reducing the value of an asset over a period of years
anachronism: locating something at a time when it couldn't have existed
analgesia: absence of the sense of pain without loss of consciousness
antithetical: sharply contrasted in character or purpose
apostate: not faithful to religion or party or cause
apostle: an ardent early supporter of a cause or reform
apposite: being of striking appropriateness and pertinence
appropriate: suitable for a particular person, place, or situation

arrogate: seize and take control without authority
assiduous: marked by care and persistent effort
attenuate: become weaker, in strength, value, or magnitude
attune: adjust or accustom to; bring into harmony with
augury: an event indicating important things to come

balloon: small thin inflatable rubber bag with narrow neck
banal: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse
bay: an indentation of a shoreline smaller than a gulf
bent: stooped (used of the back and knees)
besiege: surround so as to force to give up
bilk: cheat somebody out of what is due, especially money

bucolic: devoted to raising sheep or cattle

catholic: comprehensive or broad-minded in tastes and interests
chicanery: the use of tricks to deceive someone

diaphanous: so thin as to transmit light

dovetail: a mortise joint formed by interlocking parts
droll: comical in an odd or whimsical manner
duplicity: the act of deceiving or acting in bad faith
echelon: level of authority in a hierarchy
effrontery: audacious behavior that you have no right to
egress: the act or means of going out
elegy: a mournful poem; a lament for the dead
emaciate: grow weak and thin or waste away physically
endemic: native to or confined to a certain region
epicure: a person devoted to refined sensuous enjoyment
ersatz: an artificial or inferior substitute or imitation
ethos: the distinctive spirit of a culture or an era
euphemism: an inoffensive expression substituted for an offensive one
exonerate: pronounce not guilty of criminal charges
expurgate: edit by omitting or modifying parts considered indelicate

fecund: capable of producing offspring or vegetation

fledgling: young bird that has just become capable of flying

grandstand: a stand at a racecourse or stadium consisting of tiers with rows of individual seats that are under a protective roof
grating: unpleasantly harsh or grating in sound
grievous: causing or marked by grief or anguish
grouse: popular game bird having a plump body and feathered legs

hew: make or shape as with an axe
hoary: having gray or white hair as with age

idolatry: the worship of objects or images as gods
immutable: not subject or susceptible to change or variation
impasse: a situation in which no progress can be made

impermeable: preventing especially liquids to pass or diffuse through

impervious: not admitting of passage or capable of being affected

impious: lacking piety or reverence for a god
implacable: incapable of being appeased or pacified

inconstancy: the quality of being changeable and variable
inculcate: teach and impress by frequent repetitions or admonitions
indefatigable: showing sustained enthusiasm with unflagging vitality

inert: unable to move or resist motion
inexorable: impossible to prevent, resist, or stop

iniquity: absence of moral or spiritual values

insinuate: suggest in an indirect or covert way; give to understand
insipid: lacking interest or significance or impact

inter: place in a grave or tomb

intransigent: impervious to pleas, persuasion, requests, or reason
inundate: fill or cover completely, usually with water
inure: cause to accept or become hardened to

inveigle: influence or urge by gentle urging, caressing, or flattering

invidious: containing or implying a slight or showing prejudice
irresolute: uncertain how to act or proceed

larceny: the act of taking something from someone unlawfully

leery: openly distrustful and unwilling to confide

lurid: glaringly vivid and graphic; marked by sensationalism
machination: a crafty and involved plot to achieve your ends

manifest: clearly revealed to the mind or the senses or judgment

mendicant: a pauper who lives by begging

missive: a written message addressed to a person or organization

modish: in the current fashion or style
molt: cast off hair, skin, horn, or feathers
monastic: of communal life sequestered under religious vows
myopic: unable to see distant objects clearly

nettle: plant having stinging hairs that cause skin irritation
noisome: causing or able to cause nausea

normative: relating to or dealing with typical standards or patterns
oblique: slanting or inclined in direction or course or position

palliate: lessen or to try to lessen the seriousness or extent of
pallid: deficient in color suggesting physical or emotional distress

pastiche: a work of art that imitates the style of some previous work

posit: take as a given; assume as a postulate or axiom

surly: unfriendly and inclined toward anger or irritation

stertorous: of breathing having a heavy snoring sound

presage: a foreboding about what is about to happen

quisling: someone who collaborates with an enemy occupying force

antagonism: an actively expressed feeling of dislike and hostility

impetus: a force that makes something happen

moiety: one of two approximately equal parts

purport: have the often specious appearance of being or intending
candidly: it is sincerely the case that

forbearance: a delay in enforcing rights or claims or privileges

obstinate: marked by tenacious unwillingness to yield

bristly: having or covered with protective barbs or spines

obtuse: of an angle, between 90 and 180 degrees
Byzantine: highly complex or intricate and occasionally devious
cumbersome: difficult to handle or use because of size or weight
mettlesome: having a proud, courageous, and unbroken spirit
deliquesce: melt or become liquid by absorbing moisture from the air
impending: close in time; about to occur
stodgy: excessively conventional and unimaginative and hence dull
visceral: relating to or affecting the internal organs

maven: one who is very skilled in or knowledgeable about a field
doyen: a man who is the senior member of a group

amorphous: having no definite form or distinct shape
efficacious: giving the power to produce an intended result
calumniate: charge falsely or with malicious intent
dross: worthless or dangerous material that should be removed

quotidian: found in the ordinary course of events
bowdlerize: edit by omitting or modifying parts considered indelicate

ennui: the feeling of being bored by something tedious

corporeal: having material or physical form or substance

edifying: enlightening or uplifting so as to encourage improvement
expatiate: add details, as to an account or idea

subtle: difficult to detect or grasp by the mind or analyze
palatable: acceptable to the taste or mind

complicity: guilt as a confederate in a crime or offense

somber: grave or even gloomy in character

condescending: characteristic of those who treat others with arrogance

elated: exultantly proud and joyful; in high spirits

hiatus: an interruption in the intensity or amount of something
futility: uselessness as a consequence of having no practical result

gothic: characterized by gloom and mystery and the grotesque
epoch: a period marked by distinctive character

piety: righteousness by virtue of being religiously devout

abate: become less in amount or intensity
aberrant: markedly different from an accepted norm
admonish: scold or reprimand; take to task
aesthetic: characterized by an appreciation of beauty or good taste
aggregate: a sum total of many heterogeneous things taken together
alleviate: provide physical relief, as from pain
ambiguous: having more than one possible meaning
analogous: similar or equivalent in some respects
anarchy: a state of lawlessness and disorder
anomalous: deviating from the general or common order or type
apathy: an absence of emotion or enthusiasm
arduous: characterized by effort to the point of exhaustion
artless: simple and natural; without cunning or deceit
ascetic: someone who practices self denial as a spiritual discipline
assuage: provide physical relief, as from pain
audacious: disposed to venture or take risks
austere: of a stern or strict bearing or demeanor
boorish: ill-mannered and coarse in behavior or appearance
buttress: a support usually of stone or brick

commensurate: corresponding in size or degree or extent

conciliatory: making or willing to make concessions

contention: the act of competing as for profit or a prize

disjointed: taken apart at the points of connection
document: a representation of a person's thinking with symbolic marks
dormant: inactive but capable of becoming active

impede: be a hindrance or obstacle to

metamorphosis: striking change in appearance or character or circumstances
meticulous: marked by precise accordance with details
mitigate: lessen or to try to lessen the seriousness or extent of
mollify: cause to be more favorably inclined
mundane: found in the ordinary course of events

partisan: a fervent and even militant proponent of something
pathological: relating to the study of diseases
pedantic: marked by a narrow focus on or display of learning
permeable: allowing fluids or gases to pass or diffuse through
placate: cause to be more favorably inclined
plasticity: the property of being physically malleable

prohibitive: tending to discourage, especially of prices

quibble: evade the truth of a point by raising irrelevant objections

reverent: feeling or showing profound respect or veneration

savor: a particular taste or smell, especially an appealing one

spectrum: a broad range of related objects, values, or qualities
sporadic: recurring in scattered or unpredictable instances
substantiate: establish or strengthen as with new evidence or facts

venerate: regard with feelings of respect and reverence
verbose: using or containing too many words
viscous: having a relatively high resistance to flow
volatile: liable to lead to sudden change or violence

adamant: very hard native crystalline carbon valued as a gem
adept: having or showing knowledge and skill and aptitude
aesthete: one who professes great sensitivity to the beauty of art
affliction: a cause of great suffering and distress
affluent: having an abundant supply of money or possessions of value

ambivalent: uncertain or unable to decide about what course to follow
annotate: add explanatory notes to or supply with critical comments
antediluvian: of or relating to the period before the biblical flood

aphoristic: terse and witty and like a maxim
aqueous: similar to or containing or dissolved in water

assess: estimate the nature, quality, ability or significance of
astringent: tending to draw together or constrict soft organic tissue
atone: turn away from sin or do penitence
atrophy: a decrease in size of an organ caused by disease or disuse
auspicious: indicating favorable circumstances and good luck
avid: marked by active interest and enthusiasm
bask: expose oneself to warmth and light, as for relaxation

bizarre: conspicuously or grossly unconventional or unusual

bog: wet spongy ground of decomposing vegetation

cant: a slope in the turn of a road or track

cavern: a large cave or a large chamber in a cave
censor: a person authorized to suppress unacceptable material
charter: a document creating an institution and specifying its rights
circumlocution: an indirect way of expressing something
clot: a lump of material formed from the content of a liquid
clumsy: lacking grace in movement or posture
coerce: cause to do through pressure or necessity
cognizance: the state or act of having knowledge of
coherent: marked by an orderly and consistent relation of parts

conceit: the trait of being unduly vain
conducive: tending to bring about; being partly responsible for
conflagration: a very intense and uncontrolled fire

conjecture: believe especially on uncertain or tentative grounds

consensus: agreement in the judgment reached by a group as a whole

console: give moral or emotional strength to
conspicuous: obvious to the eye or mind

consternation: sudden shock or dismay that causes confusion
contingent: determined by conditions or circumstances that follow
controversial: marked by or capable of arousing disagreement
corporal: affecting the body as opposed to the mind or spirit
coy: affectedly shy especially in a playful or provocative way
crave: have an appetite or great desire for

crockery: ceramic dishes used for serving food
curb: the act of restraining power or action or limiting excess

deft: skillful in physical movements; especially of the hands

digress: wander from a direct or straight course

disdain: lack of respect accompanied by a feeling of intense dislike

disparity: inequality or difference in some respect
dispassionate: unaffected by strong emotion or prejudice
dispel: cause to separate and go in different directions

drab: a dull greyish to yellowish or light olive brown
drawl: a slow speech pattern with prolonged vowels
drone: make a monotonous low dull sound
dumbfound: be a mystery or bewildering to

efface: remove by or as if by rubbing or erasing
egregious: conspicuously and outrageously bad or reprehensible

enchant: cast a spell over someone or something
encumber: hold back, impede, or weigh down
engrossed: giving or marked by complete attention to
enigma: something that baffles understanding and cannot be explained
ensign: a person who holds a commissioned rank in the U.S. Navy
eradicate: destroy completely, as if down to the roots
espouse: choose and follow a theory, idea, policy, etc.
evict: expel or eject without recourse to legal process
evoke: call forth, as an emotion, feeling, or response

extant: still in existence; not extinct or destroyed or lost
extempore: with little or no preparation or forethought
extensive: large in spatial extent or range or scope or quantity
extent: the point or degree to which something extends
faddish: intensely fashionable for a short time
fallacy: a misconception resulting from incorrect reasoning
falter: move hesitatingly, as if about to give way
fanatical: marked by excessive enthusiasm for a cause or idea
fathom: a linear unit of measurement for water depth
feign: make believe with the intent to deceive

feud: a bitter quarrel between two parties
flamboyant: tending to attract attention; marked by ostentatious display
flimsy: a thin strong lightweight translucent paper
flinch: draw back, as with fear or pain
flippant: showing an inappropriate lack of seriousness

fluffy: like down or as soft as down
flustered: thrown into a state of agitated confusion
foible: a minor weakness or peculiarity in someone's character
foppish: affecting extreme elegance in dress and manner

formidable: extremely impressive in strength or excellence

frivolous: not serious in content or attitude or behavior

gird: bind with something round or circular
gist: the central meaning or theme of a speech or literary work
gorge: a deep ravine, usually with a river running through it
gossamer: a gauze fabric with an extremely fine texture

grill: a framework of metal bars used as a partition or a grate
grudging: petty or reluctant in giving or spending

guile: shrewdness as demonstrated by being skilled in deception

hypocritical: professing feelings or virtues one does not have

impromptu: with little or no preparation or forethought

incipient: only partly in existence; imperfectly formed
incongruous: lacking in harmony or compatibility or appropriateness

insignia: a badge worn to show official position

jamb: a vertical side piece of a door or window frame

jocular: characterized by jokes and good humor
jovial: full of or showing high-spirited merriment
judicious: marked by the exercise of common sense in practical matters

leaven: a substance used to produce fermentation in dough
lethargy: inactivity; showing an unusual lack of energy

limp: walk impeded by some physical injury

literal: limited to the explicit meaning of a word or text

loom: a textile machine for weaving yarn into a textile
mace: a ceremonial staff carried as a symbol of office

meager: deficient in amount or quality or extent

metaphysics: the philosophical study of being and knowing
misogynist: a misanthrope who dislikes women in particular
moat: ditch dug as a fortification and usually filled with water

narcotic: a drug that produces numbness or stupor
neuralgia: acute spasmodic pain along the course of one or more nerves
nocturnal: belonging to or active during the night
nonchalant: marked by casual unconcern or indifference

oblation: the act of contributing to the funds of a church or charity
obliquity: the quality of being deliberately vague or deceptive
oblivion: the state of being disregarded or forgotten
obsession: an unhealthy and compulsive preoccupation with something
obsidian: glass formed by the cooling of lava without crystallization
obvious: easily perceived by the senses or grasped by the mind
occult: supernatural forces and events and beings collectively
oculist: a person skilled in testing for defects of vision
odoriferous: emitting a smell, especially an unpleasant smell

offertory: the offerings of the congregation at a religious service
ogle: stare or look at, especially with amorous intentions
olfactory: of or relating to the sense of smell
oligarchy: a political system governed by a few people
ominous: threatening or foreshadowing evil or tragic developments
omnivorous: feeding on both plants and animals
onomatopoeia: using words that imitate the sound they denote
opalescent: having a play of lustrous rainbow colors
opaque: not transmitting or reflecting light or radiant energy
opportune: suitable or advantageous especially for a particular purpose

optimum: most desirable possible under a restriction

opulence: wealth as evidenced by sumptuous living
opus: a musical work that has been created
oratorio: a musical composition for voices and orchestra
orientation: the act of determining one's position
orifice: an opening, especially one that opens into a bodily cavity
ornate: marked by complexity and richness of detail
ornithology: the branch of zoology that studies birds
orthography: representing the sounds of a language by written symbols
ossified: set in a rigidly conventional pattern of behavior or beliefs
ostracism: the act of excluding someone from society by general consent

outgrowth: the gradual beginning or coming forth
outset: the time at which something is supposed to begin
overhaul: make repairs, renovations, revisions or adjustments to
overt: open and observable; not secret or hidden
overture: orchestral music at the beginning of an opera or musical

pathology: the branch of medical science that studies diseases
pedestrian: a person who travels by foot
perch: an elevated place serving as a seat
peremptory: putting an end to all debate or action
perplex: be a mystery or bewildering to

pitch: the high or low quality of a sound

plod: walk heavily and firmly, as when weary, or through mud

ponderous: having great mass and weight and unwieldiness
posture: the arrangement of the body and its limbs

precedence: status established in order of importance or urgency
premise: a statement that is held to be true
prerogative: a right reserved exclusively by a person or group
prescience: the power to foresee the future

profuse: produced or growing in extreme abundance
prolong: lengthen in time; cause to be or last longer
prompt: according to schedule or without delay
proposition: a suggestion offered for acceptance or rejection

provocative: serving or tending to excite or stimulate
prune: cultivate, tend, and cut back the growth of

pugnacious: ready and able to resort to force or violence
pundit: a person with special knowledge who performs skillfully
quack: the harsh sound of a duck

quenching: the act of extinguishing; causing to stop burning
quiescence: a state of possibly temporary inaction or dormancy
quintessential: representing the perfect example of a class or quality
ramification: a consequence, especially one that causes complications

ranger: an official responsible for managing an area of forest
rarefy: lessen the density or solidity of
rationale: an explanation of the fundamental reasons
recede: pull back or move away or backward
reciprocal: concerning each of two or more persons or things
reckless: marked by defiant disregard for danger or consequences
recourse: act of turning to for assistance
redeem: exchange or buy back for money; under threat
refurbish: improve the appearance or functionality of

remorse: a feeling of deep regret, usually for some misdeed
salvage: rescuing a ship or its crew from a shipwreck or a fire
shrill: having or emitting a high-pitched and sharp tone or tones
shuck: material consisting of seed coverings and small pieces of stem or leaves that have been separated from the seeds
shun: avoid and stay away from deliberately

skeptical: marked by or given to doubt
sketchy: giving only major points; lacking completeness
skiff: a small boat propelled by oars or by sails or by a motor

sober: not affected by a chemical substance, especially alcohol

spine: the series of vertebrae forming the backbone
stake: a strong wooden or metal post driven into the ground
steadfast: marked by firm determination or resolution; not shakable
stiff: incapable of or resistant to bending
stigmatize: condemn or openly brand as disgraceful

substantial: real; having a material or factual existence
supplicate: ask for humbly or earnestly, as in prayer
susceptible: yielding readily to or capable of
tangible: perceptible by the senses, especially the sense of touch
tapestry: a wall hanging of heavy fabric with pictorial designs
tarnish: make or become dirty or spotty

tentative: hesitant or lacking confidence; unsettled in mind or opinion
torment: intense feelings of suffering; acute mental or physical pain

unequivocal: admitting of no doubt or misunderstanding
untenable: incapable of being defended or justified

uphold: stand up for; stick up for; of causes, principles, or ideals

vertigo: a reeling sensation; a feeling that you are about to fall
vigilance: the process of paying close and continuous attention

volubility: the quality of being facile in speech and writing

zenith: the point above the observer directly opposite the nadir
